title: 106_hr909
content: The Act may be cited as the "Y2K State and Local GAP (Government Assistance Programs) Act of 1999". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act, known as the "Y2K State and Local GAP (Government Assistance Programs) Act of 1999," outlines various welfare programs including TANF, Medicaid, food stamps, WIC, child support enforcement, and child welfare programs. The curr_chunk discusses definitions related to child welfare programs, child care, and Y2K compliance in information technology. SEC. 3. Grants to states for Y2K compliance in government programs. The Secretary of Commerce will award grants to States for Y2K compliance in government programs, with priority given to Federal welfare programs. Limitations include a maximum of 75 grants and 2 grants per State. States can apply through the State Governor's Office within 45 days of enactment. The Secretary of Commerce will award grants to States for Y2K compliance in government programs. Applications for the grant must include a proposed plan, budget, and funding source. States awarded a grant must match $1 for every $2 awarded to carry out the development and implementation. The section requires States to match $1 for every $2 awarded under the grant for Y2K compliance programs. The Secretary of Commerce can waive the matching requirement for States facing undue hardship. State expenditures can be in cash or in kind, including equipment or services, with no credit for pre-award expenditures. The Secretary of Commerce evaluates grant applications based on feasibility and achieving program goals. Grants are awarded for a maximum of 2 years, with funds available until expended. States must submit annual reports on program results. The Secretary of Commerce evaluates grant applications based on feasibility and program goals. Grants are awarded for up to 2 years, with funds available until expended. A report to Congress is required within 90 days after the termination of grants, evaluating the programs funded. Authorization of $40,000,000 for fiscal years 1999 to 2001 is provided from Y2K Emergency Supplemental Funds.
